title: In-class Exercise 4: Geographically Weighted Summary Statistics - GWmodel
text:
Import the relevant R package

pacman::p_load(GWmodel, sf, spdep, tmap, tidyverse, knitr, ggstatsplot)

title: In-class Exercise 4: Geographically Weighted Summary Statistics - GWmodel
text:
2.1 Hunan Shapefile

hunan <- st_read(dsn = "data/geospatial", 
                 layer = "Hunan")

Reading layer `Hunan' from data source 
  `C:\thuphuong1110\ISSS626-GAA\In-class_Ex\In-class_Ex04\data\geospatial' 
  using driver `ESRI Shapefile'
Simple feature collection with 88 features and 7 fields
Geometry type: POLYGON
Dimension:     XY
Bounding box:  xmin: 108.7831 ymin: 24.6342 xmax: 114.2544 ymax: 30.12812
Geodetic CRS:  WGS 84

title: In-class Exercise 4: Geographically Weighted Summary Statistics - GWmodel
text:
2.2 Hunan 2012 Data

hunan2012 <- read_csv("data/aspatial/Hunan_2012.csv")

Rows: 88 Columns: 29
── Column specification ────────────────────────────────────────────────────────
Delimiter: ","
chr  (2): County, City
dbl (27): avg_wage, deposite, FAI, Gov_Rev, Gov_Exp, GDP, GDPPC, GIO, Loan, ...

ℹ Use `spec()` to retrieve the full column specification for this data.
ℹ Specify the column types or set `show_col_types = FALSE` to quiet this message.

title: In-class Exercise 4: Geographically Weighted Summary Statistics - GWmodel
text:
2.3 Join Hunan and Hunan 2012 data
The following code chunk uses left_join() from the dplyr package to update the attribute table of hunan’s SpatialPolygonsDataFrame by merging it with the attribute fields from the hunan2012 dataframe.

hunan_sf <- left_join(hunan,hunan2012, by = "County" ) %>%
  select(1:3, 7, 15, 16, 31, 32)

title: In-class Exercise 4: Geographically Weighted Summary Statistics - GWmodel
text:
4.1 Determine adaptive bandwidth

4.1.1 Cross-validation
Cross validation of different bandwidth values is calculated using below code chunk, using approach = CV, longlat = T (to indicate the use of coordinates in degree)

bw_CV = bw.gwr(GDPPC ~ 1, 
               data = hunan_sp,
               approach = "CV",
               adaptive = TRUE,
               kernel = "bisquare",
               longlat = T)

Adaptive bandwidth: 62 CV score: 15515442343 
Adaptive bandwidth: 46 CV score: 14937956887 
Adaptive bandwidth: 36 CV score: 14408561608 
Adaptive bandwidth: 29 CV score: 14198527496 
Adaptive bandwidth: 26 CV score: 13898800611 
Adaptive bandwidth: 22 CV score: 13662299974 
Adaptive bandwidth: 22 CV score: 13662299974 



bw_CV

[1] 22




4.1.2 AIC

bw_AIC = bw.gwr(GDPPC ~ 1, 
               data = hunan_sp,
               approach = "AIC",
               adaptive = TRUE,
               kernel = "bisquare",
               longlat = T)

Adaptive bandwidth (number of nearest neighbours): 62 AICc value: 1923.156 
Adaptive bandwidth (number of nearest neighbours): 46 AICc value: 1920.469 
Adaptive bandwidth (number of nearest neighbours): 36 AICc value: 1917.324 
Adaptive bandwidth (number of nearest neighbours): 29 AICc value: 1916.661 
Adaptive bandwidth (number of nearest neighbours): 26 AICc value: 1914.897 
Adaptive bandwidth (number of nearest neighbours): 22 AICc value: 1914.045 
Adaptive bandwidth (number of nearest neighbours): 22 AICc value: 1914.045 



bw_AIC

[1] 22

title: In-class Exercise 4: Geographically Weighted Summary Statistics - GWmodel
text:
4.3 Compute geographically weighted summary statistics

gwstat = gwss(data = hunan_sp,
              vars = "GDPPC",
              bw = bw_AIC,
              kernel = "bisquare",
              adaptive = TRUE,
              longlat = T)

Taking a look at the gwstat gwss object:

GDPPC_LM: the local means of 22 neighbours calculated for all the points
GDPPC_LVar: the local variance of 22 neighbours calculated for all the points

title: In-class Exercise 4: Geographically Weighted Summary Statistics - GWmodel
text:
4.4 Prepare the output data
The code chunk below is used to extract SDF data table from gwss object (output from gwss()). It is converted into data.frame using as.data.frame().

gwstat_df = as.data.frame(gwstat$SDF)

Next cbind() is used to append the newly derived data.frame onto hunan_sf sf data frame.

hunan_gstat = cbind(hunan_sf, gwstat_df)

title: Geospatial Analytics and Application (ISSS626)
text:
1 Welcome to my Geospatial Analytics Learning Journey
Hello there! I am Phuong. Welcome to my ISSS626 Geospatial Analysis and Application homepage. This course is taught by Prof KAM Tin Seong as part of my Master of IT in Business program at Singapore Management University. In this website, you will find my coursework prepared for this course, encompassing practical application of different techniques to transform and analyze spatial data.


2 Website Sections
The coursework is divided into 3 main sections:









Hands-on Exercise







In-class Exercise







Take-home Exercise






Hands-on Exercise: Hands-on practice under the guidance given by Prof Kam, using relevant R packages to perform geospatial analysis using public data sources.
In-class Exercise: Extend from the methods learned through Hands-on Exercise and include analysis result communication through data visualization.
Take-home Exercise: Synthesize learning from course materials and above exercises to analyze real-world geospatial cases.
